D:/GDA/gda-trunk/users/scripts/scanExplain.py

Go to the documentation of this file.
00001 #
00002 #  Scanning
00003 #
00004 
00005 # These operate the chi, phi and theta arms of the diffractometer and use an eight channel countertimer named 't'
00006 
00007 # Have values of chi, phi and theta display and update in the Terminal window:
00008 watch chi phi theta
00009 
00010 # Find out about chi
00011 chi
00012 
00013 # Move chi to 50
00014 pos chi 50
00015 
00016 # Move chi back by 1
00017 inc chi -1
00018 
00019 # Obtain full position of all Scannables:
00020 list Scannable
00021 
00022 # Set 't' to be implicitly used in every scan:  (if you don’t do this, then add 't' to the end of the other commands below)
00023 add default t
00024 
00025 # Scan over chi
00026 scan chi 10 12 1
00027 
00028 # Same scan but include current position of phi in every print out
00029 scan chi 10 12 1 phi
00030 
00031 # Same scan, but ensure phi is at 20
00032 scan chi 10 12 1 phi 20
00033 
00034 # This time start phi at 20, but move it by 1 every step
00035 scan chi 10 12 1 phi 20 1
00036 
00037 # Grid scan, where every point of phi and chi from 10 to 12 are operated:
00038 scan chi 10 12 1 phi 10 12 1
00039 
00040 
00041 
00042 # In fact it is easy for users to write their own Scannables (like VM's in JCLAM or Pseudo Motors in SPEC).  To do this, a minimum of only three methods need to be written - so its quick to write them.
00043 # Scannables have levels so they are operated in order during a scan.
00044 # Scannables can be set to be 'default'  (see the add default above) so they are implicitly operated in every scan.
00045 #The data points from each scan will be shown in the display.  To have each scan plot to a brand new graph, then check the tick box at the bottom of the plotting area on the Terminal tab
